newsitem.title: USA: Push comes to shove in Internet delivery market.
newsitem.headline: Push comes to shove in Internet delivery market.

text.p: In a sign of intensifying competition in the nascent market for delivering content automatically over the Internet, one rival is prepared to offer competitive discounting.

Adapting competitive marketing tactics of the consumer and shrink-wrapped software business to the Internet market is Wayfarer Communications, one of more than two dozen companies now offering push technology.
"Push computing" describes the concept of sending automatic updates of news, advertising, software and other products over the Internet or internal corporate networks known as intranets.

A representative of Wayfarer said the company will from March 31 begin offering a "20/20 Vision" promotion in which it will charge for a 20-day evaluation of its INCISA product and a 20 percent discount for customers who install INCISA instead of consumer-based push approaches.

PointCast Network, which spearheaded the push market a year ago when it introduced software which computer users could install to receive regular updates of news and data, along with advertising which supports the model.
Wayfarer is expected to announce the new promotional pricing plan on Monday, the representative said.

The pricing strategy aims to differentiate Wayfarer from rivals, such as PointCast and BackWeb, whose products Wayfarer said contain advertising and other non-business content which it claims can be distracting to employees.
Wayfarer also says its technology can filter and push new information in real time, rather than many other technologies which instead "pull" down the information at designated intervals.
Wayfarer's INCISA server is priced starting at $5,000 for 100 seats with discounts for higher-volume purchases.
The 20/20 Vision program provides a 20-day evaluation at no charge and a $1,000 credit to customers who replace a PointCast or BackWeb server with INCISA through May 30.

Ira Machefsky, an analyst at market consultants Giga, said the 20/20 program could diminish "buyers remorse" by among companies seeking to deploy push capabilities on internal networks by encouraging comparative testing.

Wayfarer is privately financed, with investors including Sequoia Capital, Hummer/Winblad Venture Partners, Robertson Stephens and Co., Bay Partners, and Stanford University. ((sam.perry@reuters.com, Palo Alto Bureau 415 846 5400))
